As for details from those who submit the node for consideration, see [What is Consideration?] for more on this. In particular "title of 'help' should be changed" is a pretty bad example in my book. "Change title to 'specific title suggestion goes here'" is what I want to see.

[Masem] 2001-09-19, ~8:30 CDT

A good number of us editors just got finishing up cleaning a mess that a user ([Juo], in this case), made when they tried to repost their question several times, trying to obviously post-edit the formating after submission. That user ended up posting about 18 copies of the same question within 10 minutes. I doubt that it was meant to be malicious, but it did have us editors running ragged.

I've got a suggestion that might help in the future; Only a power for editors and possibly Level 10's, however. Upon visiting a user's node page, the "consideration nodelet" would be available and have a form for "Block this user" with a reason. Just like Nodes to Consider, this would be recorded somewhere with the person that initiated the block. When blocked, the target user can not post for some time (4 hrs seems reasonable), at which point the block is automatically removed. The user should also be told he is blocked for the message given by the upper-level person. If the user has to be blocked again, the block should be in place until it is removed manually by Vroom or some other upper level monk. Possibly a third block means loss of the PM account, but this is debatable if we need to go this far.

Obviously, there's potental for abuse here, which is why the power must be limited. In addition, the person that places the block must be accountable for why the block was in place, and any abuse can be dealt with on a case-by-case basis. (I don't expect that to happen, but we have that outlet to justify it). It should only be used in a case like today, when a user is posting too many duplicates of the same question, as I can easily see that being extended to someone maliciously doing a DOS attack on PM. It should NOT be used to stop someone putting their foot in their mouth such as in the sierrathedog04 "Surprised by Reality" thread, at least, IMO.

It's probably not critical, but it should be a strong consideration on the to-do list.
